question: Really fucking awesome.

question: Come on sleeping beauty, time to go to work.

question: Rise and shine.

question: How long have you been running this place?

answer: I don't drive cross country.

question: But if you did.

question: But suppose for a second you did.

question: No, no I think it's really interesting.

question: I swear I've aged five years since this trip started.

question: I don't know. Couple hours I think. I've got to call him.

question: Yeah, I hit burn out mode back at that old stripper lady's place. Watching her dance around with those ratty-looking animals was ridiculous.

question: A decent meal every once in a while wouldn't hurt either, this road food is crap.

question: Scattered, smothered and covered.
answer: Exactly... well, I guess a couple more photos won't kill me.

question: Hello... ...hey Denise... what, what's wrong, did you break down?
answer: No, nothing like that... yeah, we're gonna be a little late. We stopped for gas at this place called Capt. Spaulding's outside of Ruggsville and it turned into a whole thing, so we're kind of behind schedule.

question: Oh yeah, yeah I've driven by that place before. I seem to remember a crabby old bastard in a crummy clown suit running the place.
answer: Yeah, well he's still here. I think him and Jerry are fast becoming buddies, you know Jerry... yeah, he's gotta see everything... yeah, I know... thinks there's some unsolved mystery around every corner.

question: Well, don't take too long, the kids are already knocking down the door demanding their sugar fix... I know, I know I forgot to mention that Halloween falls on a school night, so they're trick or treating tonight... I got the joint decked out this year, built a graveyard in the front yard like when you were a kid.
answer: Hopefully I can move things along here and make up the lost time by speeding all the way home... yes, Dad I'm kidding.

question: Whoa, thanks for stopping. I been standing out there in that toad strangling rain for like a hundred million years.

question: Yeah, most people just whiz on by like I was invisible or something... or else they're creeps who wanna jam their slimy hands down my pants and twiddle my naughty-naughty.

question: Couple more miles up this road.
answer: Hey, you might know... ...you know where this tree is at? It's an old hanging tree from...

answer: Really, wow, so it's really a real thing.

question: Yeah, it's a tree. I used to play there all the time. But, you can't find it without me. Outsider can't find no deadwood.
answer: Deadwood, is that what it's called? Cool, will you show us?

question: Maybe, maybe, maybe... hey, you know what word I hate?
answer: What?

question: Cone.
answer: Huh... what cone?

question: Any cone, yeah... I hate that word... sounds ugly, I don't like crumple either.
answer: I always hate saying the word cheese, every time you get your picture taken... smile, say cheese.

question: OK, let's relax. I'll check it, maybe I'm wrong. Don't everybody freak out just yet.

question: Gee, ya think it wouldn't be too much trouble. I hope you fixed the spare like I asked ya.

question: Jesus Christ, Jerry.
answer: Well, technically I did what ya said.

question: Can I help you with something?

question: What?

question: Do you believe this fucking girl?

question: Fuck, it's freezing.

question: Oh, yeah.
answer: Yeah, in this book there's a chapter called Self Made Freaks about how people would mutilate themselves in order to work in a freak show. It mostly talks about tattooed people and wild men of Borneo and shit like that, but there is one mention of a single case where a woman was suspected of having her arms removed on purpose to become an arm-less wonder.

question: Yeah, so how does that fit with the story of four morons with a flat tire looking for a dead tree?

question: So.
answer: Now she was put in the nuthouse in 1930 at the age of 16.

question: Why?

question: Yeah?
answer: These dates perfectly correspond with the time frame of our beloved Dr. Satan working at the looney bin. I'll bet he amputated her arms.

question: So what?

question: You know what Jerry, who really cares at this point?

question: I don't... ...I just thought it was weird.

question: Huh?

question: Oh, don't blow everything out of proportion.

question: How long has it been?

question: Thank you.

question: Mmmmm, this is tasty.

question: I wonder what time it is. Seems kind of late.

question: That's not something to joke about.

question: Hey, great they're back.
answer: Whoopie fucking doo.

question: His name is Rufus, Rufus Jr., but we all call him R.J.

question: What do they call you, sweety?

question: No dear, I'm fine. Now what kind of host would I be if I put my guests to this kind of work.

question: Yeah, my baby boy gets shy around new people, but he'll warm up to ya... especially the ladies.

question: For the show. It's Halloween eve and time for our show.

question: Please, come in... how many in your party... ...one, two, three and four... right this way. Please be seated.

question: Let's go see.

question: Behold... The Fish-Boy!

question: You, my dear worm feeder, are about to become immortalized.

question: Whoever's a jerking off on that bell better be gone when I get out there... 'cause I'm gonna rip your nuts off. Officers, officers what can I do for you today? I ain't fried up the birds yet... if that's what you're ring a ding dinging about.

answer: You seen this girl? Say... within the last 24 hours.

question: This and that, mostly some tired Dr. Satan bullshit... they got a gander at the display back there and thought they could solve the great Deadwoods mystery.

question: You know, his senses start tingling... when he was approaching danger and shit.

question: Hulk was dumb as shit.
answer: Aw, fuck.

question: What. Plates match.
answer: Call the chief... We found 'em.

question: Yeah, yeah... ...I like to fuck shit up.

question: Ummmm... two hundred and eighty-five dollars.
answer: Keep the change and get yourself a new name.

question: Holy crap, thanks!
answer: Come on, bro. Let's go.

question: Hey, wait take this.
answer: What's this?

question: A missing girl. I use'ta go to school with her, she just up and disappeared some day... real weird.
answer: Now isn't she a happy little cherub... oh well ...nobody just up and disappears. Yeah, maybe it was fucking aliens.

question: What'd we here, Georgie?
answer: A vehicle registered to a William S. Hudley.

question: Holy Jesus, somebody had themselves a field day beating the shit outta this thing.
answer: Yeah, no mercy here.

question: Recover any bodies?
answer: Not yet.

question: Shit, I wonder what these kids did to bring this much hell down on 'em.
answer: Just in the wrong place at the wrong time.

question: That's the understatement of the year.
answer: Yep, I suppose it is.

question: Hey, I found something.
answer: What'd ya got there?

question: Keys.
answer: Well Christ boy, don't stand there like a prize dog dick with his butthole caught up a tree.

question: Huh?
answer: Open up the trunk.

question: You sure this guy's supposed to ride with us? Seems kind of weird.
answer: Chief said pick him up and take him with us on our house to house. Guy's an ex-cop, thinks he can help.

question: Sounds like a bad idea to me, probally just get in the way.
answer: Yeah, well I guess it's tough to sit on the sidelines and wait when your own kid's missing... besides, ain't no such thing as an ex-cop.

question: I guess not.
answer: That must be him. Mr. Willis?

question: George Willis... ...any leads?
answer: Well, we were on our way out to run a check on a couple farmhouses out on the edge of town... closest thing we got to a lead at this point.

question: That's it?
answer: Well, all we know is the kids were headed out to a spot the locals call Deadwood to play Nancy Drew with some local legend about this character everybody calls Dr. Satan.

question: Don't worry about it.
answer: I don't know. I only saw one.

question: I'm sure there's more than that... fucking pigs always travel in packs... ...here, take this.
answer: What should I do?

question: Shit, don't these packrat hillbillies throw anything away?
answer: Shhhh... you hear that?

question: Yeah, I hear it... where's it coming from?
answer: Over here, inside the smokehouse.

question: Anybody in there?
answer: We gotta break it open.

question: I ain't got a warrant.
answer: Tell it to my daughter.

question: Well hello, officer.
answer: Excuse me, I'm sorry for disturbing you this fine afternoon.

question: Aw, you ain't disturbing me, but it kind of looks like rain, don't ya think?
answer: My name is Lt. Wydell, I'd like to ask you a few questions.

question: Questions? Well, heck, I'll tell you anything you want to know.
answer: I appreciate your cooperation. I'm looking for a missing girl... ...this girl here, Denise Willis... have you seen her?

question: Well, I... mmmmm... no, I ain't seen her, sorry.
answer: Please, could I please come in and talk to you for a minute? Maybe you could take a better look at the picture... might stir up something.

question: I um... no, I don't think so...
answer: Please, just a minute.

question: Oh, alright... I guess I can trust you... being a man of the law and all.
answer: Thank you.

question: We've got get out of here, we got get out of here.
answer: Think, think. Try to open the lid, try to kick a hole in the wood.

question: I can't... I can't move my arms. I hurt so much.
answer: I know, but we can make it out of here. We can do it. That was good babe, just keep doing that.

question: That's not me. I didn't... I'm not doing that.
answer: Someone is out there... ...help, we're in here!

question: Primitive wooden crosses form a circle around a burnt piece of land, approximately twenty feet in diameter.
answer: Baby sees the car and raises her gun. She aims it at the car driver. She waits, as the car gets closer she sees the face of Rufus behind the wheel. She lowers the gun and begins to laugh.

question: Tiny lifts the stake with Mary firmly strapped in place. He implants it into the ground. Her body hangs like a doll. Tiny opens a gasoline can and begins splashing gas onto the stake.
answer: Otis, face painted like a SKULL and wearing a priest's robe, walks solemnly through the tall grass.

question: Otis stands in front of the bound Mary, holding a pumpkin. Otis places the pumpkin over Mary's head.
answer: The police car drives wildly through the fields.

question: Rufus and Baby have pulled the police cruiser up by the stake. Rufus and Baby stand on the hood.
answer: Denise pulls herself to her feet and begins to run.
